intro: Brassica drepanensis, commonly known as the narrow-leafed mustard, is a flowering plant native to the Mediterranean region. It is a member of the Brassicaceae family, which includes other well-known plants like cabbage and mustard. The plant typically grows to a height of about 30–60 cm, with slender stems and small, yellow flowers arranged in racemes. Its leaves are narrow and elongated, often with a slightly hairy texture. The plant produces small, round pods that contain several seeds, which are dispersed by wind.
